Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Story:
I was folding the last of the towels when my phone buzzed. My spouse had just reminded me, for the third time today, that the laundry needed to be finished before the kids’ soccer game tomorrow. I could hear the washing machine humming, and I knew there were still two more loads to go. The expectation was clear: I needed to make sure everyone had clean uniforms and clothes for the weekend. 

Just as I was about to start the next load, my phone rang again. This time, it was Mark, an old acquaintance from work. His voice was tense—his car had broken down on a quiet road outside of town, and he didn’t know who else to call. He asked if I could come pick him up or at least wait with him until a tow truck arrived. I could hear the anxiety in his voice, and I knew he didn’t have many friends nearby. 

I stood in the laundry room, torn. My family was counting on me to keep things running smoothly at home, but Mark was reaching out in a moment of real need. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I felt my heart race as I tried to figure out what to do next.
